node.title: 2p2c miscible fluids - How to remove everything which comes with the water?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I would like to simulate water injection and production of water+CH4 in a two-phase two-component miscible system
and I hope @cpgr or @WilkAndy can help me with a question about DiracKernels.
The idea is to inject pure water into an injection well and to produce with a certain flow rate water + CH4 (in all phases).
I am not quite sure how to set the DiracKernels to remove a certain (known) rate of water (e.g. 5 kg/s)
and to remove the entire (unknown) CH4 component (as a gas and dissolved in water) so that the total mass fraction of CH4 is basically zero?
Is the way to track the amount per dt (SumQuantityUO = borehole_total_outflow_gas) correct?
Please see the attached code snipped:
[DiracKernels]
 [inject_H2O]
    type = PorousFlowPolyLineSink
    variable = pgas
    SumQuantityUO = borehole_total_inflow_water
    # mass_fraction_component = 0
    point_file = borehole_vert.bh
    fluid_phase = 0
    p_or_t_vals = '-1e9 1e9'
    fluxes = '-1 -1' # kg/m.s * 25 m length * 0.2 m borehole diameter --> 5 kg/s
  []
  [produce_H2O]
    type = PorousFlowPolyLineSink
    variable = pgas
    SumQuantityUO = borehole_total_outflow_water
    point_file = borehole_vert2.bh
    p_or_t_vals = '-1e9 1e9' # kg/m.s * 25 m length * 0.2 m borehole diameter --> 5 kg/s
    fluxes = '1 1'
  []
  [produce_CH4]
    type = PorousFlowPolyLineSink
    SumQuantityUO = borehole_total_outflow_gas
    fluxes = ??????
    p_or_t_vals = 0.0
    mass_fraction_component = 1
    point_file = borehole_vert2.bh
    variable = zi
  []
[]
Ooops, I missed this one. Did you figure it out?

I simply multiplied the flow rates by the relative permeability of the phase to get a rate. However, I am not sure if this is the correct/best solution. I thought about something like an outflowBC instead of a Dirac, but this would require an explicitly meshed cross sectional area which we don't have.
@cpgr do you have a better idea in mind how to remove fluid with a certain rate
and at the same time remove all CH4 dissolved in the water and which is present as gas phase?
In reality the CH4 gas would just migrate towards the surface in the wellbore?
And for sure, how to track the mass rates?
That's probably what I would have tried too
Is there something comparable like an outflowBC which allows for degassing within a wellbore?

node.title: 2-phase or 3-phase flow?
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I have a question:
Can the porous_flow module simulate 3-phase flow including a solid phase?
For example, if we get a precipitated solid phase by using the geochemistry module, the data from the geochemistry module will be transferred to the porous_flow module for flow calculation. Can the porous_flow module simulate precipitated solid-phase flow or not?
Best regards,
B
dear @GiudGiud and @cpgr , could you please help me with this? thanks
You can have precipitation leading to porosity reduction and permeability impairment. Is that what you mean?
Sorry, it is not. What I want to know is whether this precipitation will flow with fluid or not.
Another question: can the porous flow module simulate 3-phase flow including gas-liquid-solid?

So you want the solid phase to flow with the liquid phase I assume, with the same relative permeability? The only way I think it will do that currently is if you can express the solid phase as a liquid component - so converting the solid volume to a mass fraction of liquid volume.
All of the physics (kernels etc) are extremely general, so can handle an arbitrary number of fluid phases, with an arbitrary number of fluid components per phase. The difficulty is getting all of the fluid properties, ref perms etc correct for your model.
Sorry, the flow of the solid phase has nothing to do with the flow of the liquid phase. Can the porous flow module simulate 3-phase flow including gas-liquid-solid seperately?
I think you would have to add your own material to model this

node.title: GTN model implementation within ADViscoplasticityStressUpdate.C
node.bodyText:
Hello-
I am interested in implementing the GTN model for a study that I am doing. I noticed that the ADViscoplasticityStressUpdate material already has this model incorporated (ADViscoplasticityStressUpdate.C). After reviewing the article linked on the MOOSE Source Page V Tvergaard and A Needleman. Analysis of the cup-cone fracture in a round tensile bar. Acta Metallurgica, 32(1):157–169, 1984.; Reference 5, I am having a little trouble understanding what Lines 188 through 192 are accomplishing when calculating the residual. It appears that there is an extra term when comparing this to Equation 2.2 in the reference (although I am likely overlooking something):
 if (_pore_shape == PoreShapeModel::SPHERICAL) { residual *= 1.0 + _intermediate_porosity / 1.5;  _derivative *= 1.0 + _intermediate_porosity / 1.5; }

Also, after reviewing the source code for this material, it appears that (relative to the article provided), void nucleation has not been incorporated? (No worries if it has not as it appears fairly straight forward to incorporate).
Thank you,
-Garrett
@tophmatthews would you mind explaining this for us?

I don't think it incorporates nucleation. That model is pretty old and likely incomplete, or rather, hasn't been applied beyond test problems with great success. I've been trying to get back to it, but it seems unlikely this year.
Great, thank you both for the quick response. I will do some "digging" and update if I achieve something worth contributing.

node.title: Effect of automatic_scaling in thermal hydraulics
node.bodyText:
I am trying to fix a failing solve in my troublesome THM case by following the webpage "Troubleshooting failed solves". I think it is an issue in variable scaling in my case, so I try to use automatic_scaling = true (which did not work). So using the 01_flow_channel.i tutorial, I make the same modification (automatic_scaling=true, as given below) which seems to crash at the second time step.
My questions are: is automatic_scaling not appropriate for THM problems? Why is this simple case not working with automatic_scaling=true? Also, in general, are the guidelines in "Troubleshooting failed solves" document suitable for THM problems?
T_in = 300. # K
m_dot_in = 1e-2 # kg/s
press = 10e5 # Pa

[GlobalParams]
  initial_p = ${press}
  initial_vel = 0.0001
  initial_T = ${T_in}
  gravity_vector = '0 0 0'

  rdg_slope_reconstruction = minmod
  closures = thm_closures
  fp = he
[]

[FluidProperties]
  [he]
    type = IdealGasFluidProperties
    molar_mass = 4e-3
    gamma = 1.67
    k = 0.2556
    mu = 3.22639e-5
  []
[]

[Closures]
  [thm_closures]
    type = Closures1PhaseTHM
  []
[]

[Components]
  [inlet]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'core_chan:in'
    m_dot = ${m_dot_in}
    T = ${T_in}
  []

  [core_chan]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'
    length = 1
    n_elems = 25
    A = 7.2548e-3
    D_h = 7.0636e-2
  []

  [outlet]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'core_chan:out'
    p = ${press}
  []
[]


[Preconditioning]
  [pc]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  line_search = basic

  start_time = 0
  end_time = 1000
  dt = 10

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_max_its = 25

  automatic_scaling = true
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true

  print_linear_residuals = true
[]
[Debug]
  show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

Hello
I dont think they use it much for THM, probably because the residuals for the energy equation are initialized closer to their solution so the solver tries to over-converge them.
Also automatic scaling scales per variable and in TH simulations the friction factors difference in various components make it advantageous to scale per component
Instead they pass the scaling factors in the FlowChannel1Phase:
    scaling_factor_1phase = '1 1 1e-5'

Guillaume
Thanks!

node.title: Error when requesting u_dot_old
node.bodyText:
Hi, I was building my own material object which use _dot_old of a scalar field variable.
And I got the error

MooseVariableFE: Old time derivative of solution (u_dot_old) is not stored. Please set uDotOldRequested() to true in FEProblemBase before requesting u_dot_old.

Even I already set uDotOldRequested by _fe_problem.setUDotOldRequested(true); 
Here is my code in the construction function.
  _fe_problem.setUDotRequested(true); _fe_problem.setUDotOldRequested(true);  _var_dot = &coupledDot("coupled_variable");  _var_dot_old = &coupledDotOld("coupled_variable");
Could you help me? Thanks

Hello
This "setUDotRequested" is something that is done in the time integrator.
What time integrator are you using?
Guillaume
I use the default implicit-euler integrator of Transient Executioners.

can you add the request for UDot in ImplicitEuler.C ?
There's an example in NewmarkBeta.C for doing that

I found ImplicitEuler just inherits from TimeIntegrator where only UDotRequested is set True. Maybe I need build a new time intergrator inheriting from ImplicitEuler if I want ImplicitEuler and u_dot_old at the same time?
Yes, I will try it. Thank you~

node.title: NeumannBC on a single node
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'd like to create a single node force in MOOSE. In order to apply a NeumannBC in MOOSE a sideset is needed. However I can't seem to figure out how to create a sideset consisting of only one node. How is that done?

Hello
You cant create a sideset with a single node, you need an element side and in 2D that s 2 nodes at least.
You can create a nodeset, then look at using a NodalBC
Guillaume

Is NodalBC the same thing as NodalKernel? If not where do I find NodalBCs?
Furthermore, is there a reason why you can apply NeumannBCs to only sidesets but can't make a single node sideset? Especially in regard of said use case of applying single node forces.
A NeumannBC is an IntegratedBC. IntegratedBCs are naturally associated with surface terms in your weak form. NodalBCs perform strong constraint enforcement and are not associated with the weak form
So how would I define a force NodalBC?
I think using a ConstantRate NodalKernel on that node would accomplish what you are trying to do.
Works, thanks!

What I'm wondering though: The documentation says ConstantRate implements a kernel du/dt. Wouldn't that be velocity instead of force? A test I've run shows it acts as a force though. Where is my error in reasoning here?

IIRC the NodalKernel adds directly to the residual of the of the nodes for your case that would be force. The example given there shows how to implement du/dt = -1. Where the time derivative  kernel computes du/dt and the ConstantRate add the -1.
Ah I see. Thanks!

node.title: HPC Linux Configuration
node.bodyText:
Hello,
A Linux question, I am having an x86 HPC machine configured is there anything specific I should tell the Sys Admin on the Linux flavor or install?
Thx!
John Sevic
@milljm will be the best counsel on this

Our build farm is using Rocky-8 for most targets, and in the process for eventually transitioning to Rocky-9.
My suggestion is Rocky-9.  Or RedHat Enterprise Linux 9 [RHEL], if that is an option. Rocky is a free clone of RHEL.
OK thank you!

node.title: Background Files for Bending and Tensile Tests
node.bodyText: Hey everyone. Is there a link for the background files (such as include, src, lib, and all the others) for a bending and tensile stress? Thanks!

node.title: Boundary Generation
node.bodyText:
All,
I would like to generate boundaries. I used to do like:
[MeshModifiers]
  [./inner_BC]
  type = ParsedAddSideset
  combinatorial_geometry = 'x < 0.001'
  new_sideset_name = 'inner_boundary'
  [../]
[ ]

But, this method seems not to work any longer.
Please let me know how to generate boundaries, on which I can apply boundary conditions.
S. Thomas

MeshModifiers have been retired years ago!
We now use MeshGenerators.
For this one:
[Mesh]
  [./inner_BC]
  type = ParsedSidesetGenerator
  combinatorial_geometry = 'x < 0.001'
  new_sideset_name = 'inner_boundary'
  [../]
[ ]

Thank you, Guillaume.
I got the following error messages:
*** ERROR ***
~/mesh_generator.i:57: section '[MeshGenerators]' does not have an associated "Action".
 Common causes:
- you misspelled the Action/section name
- the app you are running does not support this Action/syntax

Please help.
S. Thomas

oh my bad
[Mesh]

Thank you, Guillaume.
It seems to be "ParsedGeneratorSideset" instead of "ParsedSidesetGenerator" :)
"ParsedGeneratorSideset" works ... thank you.
Is there anyway to delete the old boundaries?
or keeping old boundaries, which are not used any longer, doesn't harm the computation?
S. Thomas

there is this one
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/BoundaryDeletionGenerator.html
but having old boundaries does not harm anything
Thank you, Guillaume, as always. :)

node.title: Error of recompiling my application: 'not a registered file'
node.bodyText:
Hi!
I'm trying to add my own .C and .h file into my application called 'newapp', but it doesn't work. The error is :
*** ERROR ***
A 'StressSpectral' is not a registered object.

'StressSpectral.C' file and 'StressSpectral.h' file are created by myself.

Here is what I do:
- copy the .C file to newapp/src/kernels
- copy the .h file to newapp/include/kernels
- do 'make clean' to the app
- then recomplie my newapp with 'make -j 4'

I can see that the app recompiled with 'StressSpectral.C' file and 'StressSpectral.h' file.
After the recompiling was finished, I tried to run an example from moose (crack2d.i in combined modulus) and it worked well.
But when I try to run another input file with StressSpectral.C and StressSpectral.h in the new app, I got this error:
A 'StressSpectral' is not a registered object.
Do you have any idea about how to solve this problem?
Thank you.

Hello
Can you paste the registerMooseObject line in your kernel here?
And what is the name of your app in the src/base folder?

Hi!
Here is it:
registerMooseObject("TensorMechanicsApp", StressSpectralViscoPlastic);
So 'StressSpectralViscoPlastic' is the name of my .C and .h file
and the name of my app is 'bokeloh'
Here is the paths of the .C and .h file:
~/projects/bokeloh/src/kernels/StressSpectralViscoPlastic.C
~/projects/bokeloh/include/kernels/StressSpectralViscoPlastic.h
The names need to match. If you register it to stressspectralviscoplastic you need to call it that name in the input file

For the name of the app you should register it to your app not the tensor mechanics app.
If your app includes tensor mechanics then it should still work

I've changed it to:
registerMooseObject("bokelohApp", StressSpectralViscoPlastic);
and I've verified that all the modulus in the Makefile of my app bokeloh has been turned on with 'yes'.
also, tried to do 'make clobberall ' and then 'make -j 4' several times.
However, the same problem still persists.
A 'StressSpectralViscoPlastic' is not a registered object.
in the src/base/bokelohApp.C file what is the spelling of the app name exactly

Sorry for my late reply.
I changed my computer system from Centos to Ubuntu and now this problem does not appear anymore. It's a bit mysterious but the error is fixed anyway.
Thank you so much for your help.
